title: 104_hr2166
content: The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" establishes a minimum tax on certain foreign and foreign-owned corporations under Subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This new part, titled "Minimum Tax on Certain Foreign and Foreign-Owned Corporations," introduces Section 59B outlining the specifics of the minimum tax requirements. Section 59B of the "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on certain corporations based on their taxable income and gross receipts from business activities. This applies to domestic corporations that are 25-percent foreign-owned or foreign corporations with gross income. Section 59B of the "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on certain corporations with substantial foreign-related person transactions during the taxable year. This applies to domestic corporations that are 25-percent foreign-owned or foreign corporations with gross income effectively connected with a trade or business within the United States. The Secretary may approve alternative methods for determining taxable income in certain cases. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on certain corporations with substantial foreign-related person transactions. A qualified section 482 agreement with the Secretary can determine taxable income for specific business activities. The Secretary may enter into a qualified section 482 agreement to determine taxable income for specific business activities with related parties. The agreement may have retroactive effect if deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Secretary may enter into a qualified section 482 agreement for determining taxable income with related parties. The agreement can apply retroactively to prior taxable years if specified, even if not in effect when the corporation files its return. In cases where activities cannot be categorized by the Secretary based on Standard Industrial Classification Codes, an exception applies. The Secretary may impose a minimum tax of 35 percent on gross receipts from property sales or leases based on specific classifications. The section can be waived in cases of casualty or disaster deemed inequitable by the Secretary. The Secretary may waive the minimum tax on property sales or leases if deemed inequitable due to casualty or disaster. Taxable income excludes foreign taxes paid. The Secretary sets applicable profit percentages for different business activities annually. The Secretary sets applicable profit percentages for different business activities annually based on average earnings rates of domestic corporations. The earnings rate of a domestic corporation is determined by the ratio of adjusted book income to gross receipts from business activities, excluding certain taxes. For tax purposes, certain taxes like income, war profits, or excess profits taxes imposed by the US, its possessions, or foreign countries are disregarded. Definitions and rules apply, including the term '25-percent foreign-owned' and 'related party'. A corporation has substantial foreign-related person transactions if the aggregate amount involved with related parties who are foreign persons is significant. For tax purposes, substantial foreign-related person transactions occur in a taxable year if the aggregate amount with related parties who are foreign persons exceeds $2,000,000 or 10% of the corporation's gross income. Business activities are categorized by the 3-digit Standard Industrial Classification Code. The Secretary may aggregate 3-digit classifications in the Standard Industrial Classification Code for appropriate cases. A clerical amendment is made to the table of parts for subchapter A of chapter 1. Effective Date: The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
